climbs.name: 2 Tours
climbs.fa: D. Caron, M. Thériault, L. Gallant

content.description:
On the right end, locate the route with Metolius hangers. Climb the 3 small cruxes to get you to the top. Very optional BD # 0.75 at the top. 
  
 N.B. Some people are confused where to start this route. Take the path of least resistance...

Right end. Just right of Ti-Store and left of Mangeur de bas.
8 bolts

climbs.name: Baille-y de la friction
climbs.fa: M. Thériault, L. Gallant, D. Caron 2011.09.11

content.description:
This is the quintessential slab route at les Dalles. The crux is protected by 3 closely spaced bolts. Trust those feet! 
  
 Giv'er some friction!

In the middle of les dalles look for a route with 3 closely spaced bolts on a blank section.
7 bolts. Optional BD # 2 at the very top if you're timid. Bolt anchors at the top. To rap down, use rings on the route to the left or to the right.

Good footwork through the middle section of this route is the key to success.



Start near the right side of the cliff just left of the low ledge with a tree on it.

4 Bolt, Quick Clips.

Climb the obvious jug flake/rail to a small headwall.  Mantle up on the final slab and walk to the anchor.



This route starts halfway up the cliff on the ledge located to the far right.  Go to the extreme right and walk back left to easily access the ledge.

4 bolts, single rack.  Quick Clips.

A couple of tricky moves off the ground protected by bolts lead to easier climbing above.



This is the second route from the left at Les Dalles.

4 bolts, single rack up to #2.  Quick Clips.

climbs.name: Le jardinier de la dalle
climbs.fa: L. Gallant, M. Thériault, D. Caron 2011.09.11

content.description:
This is an awesome moderate mix route on les dalles. Start on the weird stump aiming for a vertical crack. Then make your way up using pockets and a big flake. Before Luc invested some time cleaning this route, it was more green than a 6th grader on a first date. This route would be a good first lead for a beginner climber and is very enjoyable for a regular climber. The route is on the left end and starts on a weird stump. Locate the vertical crank. That's the route! standard rack. 3 bolts.

Rap ring anchor.

climbs.name: Le Ti-Store
climbs.fa: M. Theaiault, L. Gallant, D. Caron, 2011

content.description:
A tricky start lasts for a few bolts before the climbing eases off and you can enjoy a fun run up to the anchor.



Located in the middle of the wall.

6 bolts. Quick clips.

A tricky start past two bolts leads to easy climbing past a tree.  Head for the obvious vertical headwall past two more bolts.

As you approach Les Dalles this is the first climb you encounter.  If you are already at the wall this is the far left climb.
Quick Clip Anchor

Bouldery Start on the detached flake to gain a ledge. From the ledge climb a few slabby moves and head for the hueco at the top. The last 10 feet is on 5.0 terrain. This is a very well protected sport climb and would be a great candidate for a first lead. In English mangeur de bas means sock eater. If you had met Dom's dog ,Tito (R.I.P.) , you'd understand... On the right end. Just right of the two 5.7's. Just look for the black bolt hangers. 6 black hangers.
Shares the same anchor as C'est loin du laundromat

Les Dalles de St-Anselme is where you come to practice your footwork. A few slabby routes can be found here. Even though these routes are slabby, they are well protected unlike typical slab routes. A new leader can therefore practice his newly acquired expertise in clipping bolts here as the proximity of bolts and the moderate grades make this cliff very user friendly. 
  
 Nota bene: Dalles means slab in french and St-Anselme is the area in Dieppe where the 3 route developpers of this crag come from.
